Football

Switch to defense made DeSales' Pirtle a star

By: Jason Frakes December 2, 2014

44 shares
share
tweet
sms
send
email

Before the 2013 season, DeSales High School football coaches knew they had to find a new position for running back Bryant Pirtle.

At 6 feet 3 and 205 pounds, Pirtle possessed the size and strength not often found at a Class 2-A school but was stuck behind a running back, Dylan Byrd, who had rushed for nearly 1,800 yards the previous season.

“Our assistant coach Jeff Poole goes, ‘We shouldn’t be wasting this kid. He’s an athlete,’ ” Colts head coach Harold Davis recalled Tuesday. “He said, ‘What do you think about trying him at defensive end?’ “

It’s been a perfect fit for Pirtle and the Colts.

Now a senior, Pirtle ranks first on the team in tackles (77), sacks (17Â½) and fumble recoveries (five) and is a big reason DeSales (13-1) is one victory away from repeating as state champion. The Colts will face Newport Central Catholic (8-5) at 3:30 p.m. EST Friday in the Class 2-A final at Houchens Industries/L.T. Smith Stadium in Bowling Green.

It’s a repeat of last year’s state final, which the Colts won 34-26. Pirtle said returning to the state final is a testament to the senior class.

“Talking to a lot of the other seniors, one of our main goals was to come back and show everybody that it wasn’t just a team of seniors last year,” he said. “It was the team as a whole. That was our main focus this year.”

Pirtle said he primarily played defense in youth leagues but focused on the running back spot during his first two seasons at DeSales. He rushed for 156 yards on 29 carries as a sophomore.

Davis said Pirtle didn’t object to the switch to defense last season.

“When we asked him, he didn’t say anything about it,” Davis said. “He said, ‘All right.’ I think he wants to be on offense and get the touchdowns, but for our team he’s so important on defense.”

Pirtle posted 66 tackles and 22Â½ sacks as a junior but was asked to do more in his senior season. With the graduation of Byrd, Pirtle has served as DeSales’ No. 2 running back behind Matt Ruxer and has rushed for 582 yards and eight touchdowns on 75 carries.

With Ruxer hobbled by an ankle injury, Pirtle could be the Colts’ featured back in Friday’s championship game. Pirtle’s season high for carries (14) came in a 35-0 victory over Southern in the regular-season finale. He had 12 carries for 110 yards in last week’s 14-7 victory over Murray.

“He’s going to get a lot of carries,” Davis said of Friday’s final. “He’s going to have to suck it up and play both ways, and hopefully he can hang in there with it.”

Pirtle said his focus remains on defense but added that he enjoys playing running back.

“I get in trouble sometimes for dancing, but in the playoffs I’ve been lowering my shoulder a little bit and using my strength,” he said.

Pirtle, who has committed to Western Kentucky, isn’t projected to have the size to play defensive end in college and likely will move to linebacker. Davis said Pirtle has the speed to prosper at linebacker, noting that he’s been clocked in the 40-yard dash at 4.5 seconds.

Pirtle said he’s looking forward to playing at WKU this weekend and remains solid in his commitment to the school, though the University of Louisville and Tennessee reportedly have been showing interest during the season.

For now, though, he’s focused on bringing DeSales its second straight state title. And he’s made his coaching staff look good for moving him to defense.

“Look at what he’s done,” Davis said. “He’s been pretty impressive.”

Jason Frakes can be reached at (502) 582-4046 and followed on Twitter @kyhighs.

STATE FOOTBALL FINALS

At Houchens Industries/L.T. Smith Stadium, Bowling Green

All times Eastern

Murray defensive back Keshon Love tries to stop the run of DeSales running back Bryant Pirtle. Pirtle’s 70-yard run set up a DeSales touchdown.
